abstract.p: Letter from Dr Markus Fischer on May 9 essay on pure world of theoretical physics; drawing

block.p: Re ''Looking Back at Pure World of Theoretical Physics'' (May 9): The essay's celebration of theoretical physics as the activity of supreme purity and intensity strikes me as a one-sided abstraction.

No doubt, the physicist's use of mathematics to uncover the fundamental properties of the material world realizes the human capacity for reason in a superb way. But can it be argued that excellence in theoretical reason entails greater purity and intensity than excellence in the other high capacities of the human soul, like artistic creativity or selfless love?
Re ''Looking Back at Pure World of Theoretical Physics'' (May 9): The essay's celebration of theoretical physics as the activity of supreme purity and intensity strikes me as a one-sided abstraction.

No doubt, the physicist's use of mathematics to uncover the fundamental properties of the material world realizes the human capacity for reason in a superb way. But can it be argued that excellence in theoretical reason entails greater purity and intensity than excellence in the other high capacities of the human soul, like artistic creativity or selfless love?
Did Newton experience greater bliss when he discovered the laws of motion than Beethoven when he composed his symphonies or Gandhi when he followed the truth of his conscience?

For the ''mathematical world without bodies, without people, without the vagaries of human emotion'' possesses not only ''certainty and power,'' as the author exults, but lacks life, humanity and moral meaning.
